text:
In 2005, Black Ops developers Treyarch found
major success developing Spider-Man 2, regarded

as not only one of the best movie licenses
ever conceived, but also one of the best open
world games in general.

So two years later, with a track record of
major success in the genre, Treyarch wanted

to create their own original IP, not bound
by licensing stipulations.

So they pitched to Activision their concept
for an all-new sandbox game, heavily influenced

by Chinese martial arts movies, and starring
a female assassin based on Lucy Liu.
That game was Black Lotus.

However, while initially greenlighting the
concept, Activison would later hate the notion

of a female protagonist, demanded several
major game-altering changes, removed Treyarch

from the project entirely, shoving them off
to make Call of Duty titles for the rest of

eternity, then ultimately cancelling the title
all-together.
So, what on Earth happened here?

Did they really cancel a game because you
played as a girl? and whatever became of this
game?

Well if those blatantly click-baitey questions
intrigue you, all I have to say is…

But, Hello you, I’m Guru Larry and I welcome
you to a Fact Hunt Special: That time Activision
Cancelled a Game Because It Starred a Woman.

Now, it’s quite easy to twist the narrative
and slap Activision with the ol’ misogyny

brush for Black Lotus’ cancellation, but
this IS the house of Bobby Kotick we’re

talking about here, and gender don’t mean
jack (or jill) to the big A if it doesn’t
bring in the moolah.

In a 2010 interview with Gamasutra, two anonymous
Treyarch employees stated: "We were all on

board, and then Activision killed it, said
they don't do female characters because they
don't sell."

And: "Activision gave us specific direction
to lose the chick,"

Shocking claims aside, looking back to when
Black Lotus was being pitched, Activision
may have some validity to their decision…

While it’s easy to say there HAVE been highly
successful and profitable female video game

characters, such as Lara Croft and Joanna
Dark, the late noughties’ weren’t exactly
the best time for logarithmic ladies.

Titles such as Bethesda’s Wet, SouthPeak’s
Velvet Assassin and EA’s Mirror’s Edge

had all being both commercial and critical
failures.

In fact, two years prior to Treyarch’s pitch,
Blue 52’s, “espionage action” game Stolen

performed so badly, it bankrupted both the
developer (Blue 52) and its publisher, Hip Games.

Did these games bomb because they starred
women?

Absolutely not no, it’s because they were
marketed poorly, and well… just weren’t
very good games in general.

It’s just easy to put 2 and 2 together thanks
to the rather unfortunate coincidence that
they all starred women.

The other main reason is Activision are like
Apple, they never try a new concept without
someone else taking the risk first.

For instance, Call of Duty would never exist
without EA’s success with Medal of Honor.

Guitar Hero would never have existed without
Konami’s Guitar Freaks’ arcade popularity.

And even Activision themselves envisioned
the Tony Hawk games to be a straight up racing

until Neversoft changed the concept to a skate
park at the last minute.

So, we’re at the point that we know that
Activision cancelled Black Lotus as they didn’t

think games that had a female protagonist
sold very well.
What happened next?

Well, Grand Theft Auto IV happened, its huge
success made Activision realize they needed

their own sandbox game as soon as possible
to rake in this potential open world goldmine…

but having nothing in development, and also
realizing they had just cancelled one, they
re-opened the project.

But taking Treyarch off the production to
focus on Call of Duty titles and gave it to

newcomer United Front Games (whose only previous
game was the PS3 exclusive Modnation Racers).

The first thing to go was obviously the female
protagonist, turning her into an undercover
male cop.

Activision also didn’t like gambling on
an all-new new IP either, so suggested it

be a sequel to one of their previous franchises
that had laid dormant for a few years.
True Crime.

Yup, Black Lotus turned into True Crime:
Hong Kong.

Now, True Crime: Hong Kong is a much more
famous cancelled game, However, Activision

threw quite a bit of money into this iteration
of the title, even hiring Hollywood voice

talent including Lucy Liu, Gwen Stacy, Liu
Kang and the bloke out of The Full Monty.

However, in their fear to create a product
that would compete with Grand Theft Auto IV,

Activision’s started to give United Front
completely unfair demands, wanting the game

to have the quality or Rockstar’s hit, (which
had a budget of $100 Million), but offering
only offering a fraction of that in funding..

So with constant delays of the game to meet
Activision’s impossible requirements, On

the 9th of February 2011, During a press release
announcing the cancelation of further Guitar

Hero games, Activision also gave a rather
vague response to True Crime: Hong Kong’s Termination.

Activison’s CEO, Eric Hirshberg would later
expand that the cancelation was because

True Crime “wasn’t good enough in quality”
while indirectly having a dig that is wasn’t
up to GTA IV’s standards.

So, Activision cut their losses and sold True
Crime: Hong Kong to Square Enix, under the

stipulation that the True Crime name couldn’t
appear anywhere within the game.

And was released two years later as Sleeping
Dogs.

Activision’s neuroticism over the quality
of the game was unfounded, as the game would

receive scores over 80% across all formats,
and would even receive another release in

2014 as a definitive edition for next gen
systems.

Thought that might be more due to Square Enix
taking a $67 million loss on the initial run.

Amazingly, there was another game set in the
Sleeping Dogs universe, though it was unclear on if

it was meant to be a sequel, or a spin off,
by the name of Triad Wars, a free-to-play

online PC game that featured co-op and perpetually
generated missions ALA Skyrim.

Triad Wars had an online beta that ran for
several months in 2015, but was ultimately

cancelled in the December with United Front
stating "We've loved seeing how you've played

Triad Wars but we know it wasn't right for
many of you."

United Front Games would close down on the
17th of October 2016, no reasons have ever
been given of their closure.

So, While it could be seen as wrong Activision
cancelling a game with a female protagonist

from today’s political climate, their decision
was entirely financially motivated.

With the nail in the coffin being their neurotic
fear of competing quality wise with a much

larger IP, but refusing to contending with
a similar budget.

It’s just a shame Activision stick to their
regime and relying on other publishers to

make mistakes, rather than take their own
gambles.

Ironically, for a video game publisher, the
only thing they’re good at playing, is playing it safe!
